required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Ventavis in Patients With Pulmonary Hypertension (PH) Secondary to Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 2, Multi-center, Double-blind, Randomized, Placebo-controlled Study to Evaluate the Effects of Inhaled Iloprost on Endurance Time During Cardiopulmonary Exercise Testing in Patients With Pulmonary Hypertension Secondary to Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

brief_summary.textblock: This is a phase 2, Multi-center, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled study to evaluate the effects of inhaled Iloprost in patients with pulmonary hypertension secondary to COPD. The main objective is to investigate the effect of iloprost on exercise endurance time during constant work rate cardiopulmonary exercise testing. Other efficacy and safety endpoints will additionally be analyzed.

primary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 4 in endurance time during constant work rate exercise testing

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline up to 24 hours post-EOT, approximately 4 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Treatment-emergent adverse events up to 24 hours post-end of treatment (EOT), approximately 4 weeks

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Systolic Pulmonary Arterial Pressure
secondary_outcome.description: On Day 1 patients underwent acute hemodynamic testing prior to and immediately after (no more than 15 minutes) the first dose of inhaled iloprost or placebo. All hemodynamic variables were measured using a Swan-Ganz catheter.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Diastolic Pulmonary Arterial Pressure
secondary_outcome.description: On Day 1 patients underwent acute hemodynamic testing prior to and immediately after (no more than 15 minutes) the first dose of inhaled iloprost or placebo. All hemodynamic variables were measured using a Swan-Ganz catheter.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Mean Pulmonary Arterial Pressure
secondary_outcome.description: On Day 1 patients underwent acute hemodynamic testing prior to and immediately after (no more than 15 minutes) the first dose of inhaled iloprost or placebo. All hemodynamic variables were measured using a Swan-Ganz catheter.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Mean Right Atrial Pressure
secondary_outcome.description: On Day 1 patients underwent acute hemodynamic testing prior to and immediately after (no more than 15 minutes) the first dose of inhaled iloprost or placebo. All hemodynamic variables were measured using a Swan-Ganz catheter.

On Day 1 patients underwent acute hemodynamic testing prior to and immediately after (no more than 15 minutes) the first dose of inhaled iloprost or placebo. All hemodynamic variables were measured using a Swan-Ganz catheter.

On Day 1 patients underwent acute hemodynamic testing prior to and immediately after (no more than 15 minutes) the first dose of inhaled iloprost or placebo. All hemodynamic variables were measured using a Swan-Ganz catheter.

On Day 1 patients underwent acute hemodynamic testing prior to and immediately after (no more than 15 minutes) the first dose of inhaled iloprost or placebo. All hemodynamic variables were measured using a Swan-Ganz catheter.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in End Tidal Partial Pressure of Carbon Dioxide
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 4. Pulmonary gas exchange was measured during incremental and constant work rate exercise testing.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in End Tidal Partial Pressure of Oxygen
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 4. Pulmonary gas exchange was measured during incremental and constant work rate exercise testing.
Change from baseline to week 4. Pulmonary gas exchange was measured during incremental and constant work rate exercise testing.
Change from baseline to week 4. Pulmonary gas exchange was measured during incremental and constant work rate exercise testing.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Oxygen Uptake Per Heartbeat
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 4. Pulmonary gas exchange was measured during incremental and constant work rate exercise testing.
Change from baseline to week 4. Heart rate was measured during incremental and constant work rate exercise testing.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Arterial Oxygen Saturation as Indicated by Pulse Oximetry
secondary_outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 4. Arterial oxygen was determined by pulse oximetry during incremental and constant work rate exercise testing.
Change from baseline to week 4. Tidal volume was measured during incremental and constant work rate exercise testing.
Change from baseline to week 4. Minute ventilation was measured during incremental and constant work rate exercise testing.

arm_group.description: single dose inhalation using the power disc-6 with I-neb Adaptive Aerosol Delivery (AAD) system
matching placebo using the power disc-6 with I-neb AAD system

intervention.description: 5ug dose of inhaled iloprost (20ug/mL solution) administered 6 to 9 times per day for 4 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Signed informed consent prior to initiation of any study mandated procedure
2. Male or female ≥ 40 and ≤ 75 years of age
3. Women of childbearing potential1 must use a reliable method of contraception
4. Clinical diagnosis of moderate to severe COPD, with an obstructive pattern on pulmonary function tests
5. Current or past smokers of ≥ 10 pack years
6. Ability to perform exercise testing without supplemental oxygen (in the best opinion of the investigator)
7. Confirmed pulmonary hypertension by right heart catheterization (RHC)
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Other causes of pulmonary hypertension than COPD
2. BMI > 35 kg/m2
3. Conditions considered as contraindications for cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) and/or inability to pedal on a cycle ergometer
4. Pregnant or nursing
5. Currently (within 30 days prior to RHC) taking specific pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) therapy (e.g., bosentan, ambrisentan, tadalafil, sildenafil, epoprostenol, treprostinil, iloprost, beraprost)
6. Participation in any other clinical trial, except observational, or receipt of an investigational product within 30 days prior to RHC visit
7. Known concomitant life-threatening disease with a life expectancy < 12 months
8. Known hypersensitivity to iloprost or any of the excipients of the drug formulations

facility.name: University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Patients were screened at 4 centres in the US, one centre in France, and one site in Spain. First patient, first visit was 1 March 2012 and last patient, last visit was 30 November 2012.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: A total of 22 patients were screened for the study, of these 20 were not randomized because they did not meet the selection criteria.

group.title: Iloprost
group.description: single dose inhalation using the power disc-6 with I-neb Adaptive Aerosol Delivery (AAD) system Iloprost: 5ug dose of inhaled iloprost (20ug/mL solution) administered 6 to 9 times per day for 4 weeks

group.title: Placebo
group.description: matching placebo using the power disc-6 with I-neb AAD system Placebo: matching placebo

participants_list.participants: Patient discontinued the study prior to initiation of study treatment

group.description: matching placebo using the power disc-6 with I-neb AAD system Placebo: matching placebo

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Change in Endurance Time
outcome.description: Change from baseline to week 4 in endurance time during constant work rate exercise testing
outcome.population: The study was prematurely terminated as after 1 year it was not possible to identify a suitable number of patients who satisfied the selection criteria. Only 2 patients were randomized prior to the termination of the study, and 1 patient received a single dose of active treatment. Therefore, there are inadequate data to evaluate efficacy.
